item.name: 1830: The Game of Railroads and Robber Barons
item.comment: I don't play it often anymore because of how long it takes to play. But once every year or two we break it out and it's like seeing an old friend. The depth, the feel... this is a classic for a reason.

item.name: 1st & Goal
item.comment:
This is quick and simple but it's possible to play well either by being entirely random or by just looking at die colors on the results table. For about two quarters it's fun and then it just feels like a grind.
It reminds me of the old NFL Strategy game by Tudor that my brother and I used to play for hours, but it's not as interesting to me now.

item.name: Agent Hunter
item.comment: This is a card counting deduction game with the theme pasted on. It's not a bad filler since you play in about 5 minutes. I'd never suggest it, but I'll play it.

item.name: Batman: Gotham City Mystery
item.comment: Not a bad game to play with the kids. The Batman theme is well executed and the figures and Batcomputer are cool. The colors on some cards are a little too hard to tell apart, but not impossible.

item.name: Batman: The Animated Series – 3D Board Game
Boss Monster: The Dungeon Building Card Game
Buffy the Vampire Slayer: The Game
item.comment: Playing this game feels exactly like watching a Buffy episode. It's remarkable that a game based on a TV series has such interesting and fun game play.

item.name: Captain Sonar
item.comment: We've played about a dozen times with 6 or 8 players. It's exciting every time. It's possible that the first mate role is a little light in choices but the other players are meaningfully engaged. Sign us up for a tournament!

item.name: Catan
item.comment: The manageable amount of luck and negotiation between players keeps this game fresh for me. It's still the most fun way to introduce new players to gaming.

item.name: Citadels
item.comment: I generally don't like card games but this is my exception. The interesting twist is that your role changes each turn, and players who are trying to gang up on the game leader have to first predict which role he'll take on that turn.

item.name: Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game
Dune: Spice Harvest
item.comment: This is an interesting game in it's own right, but as a expansion to Dune I think it too severely alters the wonderful balance of the core Dune game. We never play this anymore.

item.name: Eclipse
item.comment: I'd run out and buy this but my friend already did and we play with his set. We're new and play the game slowly, so the last time we didn't get to finish. It didn't matter. Every turn is fantastic immersive strategy and sci-fi empire building. Amazing.

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple
item.comment:
This is fun, *FAST*, and everyone is equally involved and frantic from the moment it begins. You will really *feel* the conflict of deciding to help a stranded friend (who probably can't be saved anyway) or saving yourself.
This is for gamers and non-gamers. Play the basic game with newbies twice, then bring on the advanced rules.

item.name: Evo
item.comment: This is another great game for introducing new players. The first two turns have no real consequences so you can teach the rules as you go. But by mid-game when dinosaurs are competing for good feeding and breeding ground, the tactics and tricks are as rich as almost anything. Evolving cute dinosaurs adds to the fun. I much prefer the 1st edition of this game precisely because of the fun and cartoonish design.

item.name: Explorers of the North Sea
item.comment:
After a dozen plays with 3 to 4 players: It's easy to teach, fast to play, and has a nice level of player-to-player interaction (tile lays to sabotage them, racing to "steal" livestock) without being spiteful. But what's really fun is that there seem to be several ways to win: Outposts, livestock, island control, and even raiding have worked well.
The art and components are somehow cute and gritty and top-notch. We love seeing the islands grow.

item.name: A Fake Artist Goes to New York
Flash Point: Fire Rescue
item.comment: Much easier and simpler than I thought it'd be. This feels like a kids game.

item.name: Frank Herbert's Dune
item.comment:
Dune balances combat, management of scarce resources (spice), negotiation, and timing into a game that makes every fight feel like everything is at risk. It's a koan: You win by conquering cities but not by fighting.
The more I play this game, and the more experienced the players around the table, the better it gets.

item.name: Galaxy's Edge
item.comment: I was so turned off by the generic and oversized wooden counters for this game that I haven't played it. I should have read more before buying it.

item.name: HeroQuest
item.comment: This game is AMAZING with kids between about 6 years old through 11. The closer to 6, the better.

item.name: Kittens in a Blender
item.comment: There's not much strategy to this game but it's cute and quick and we laugh a lot. It doesn't drag but I wish it took 15 minutes instead of 30 so it'd be a more clear filler. I think we're going to play this many times.

item.name: Lords of the Sierra Madre (second edition)
Méditerranée
item.comment:
I like this because you can play a strategy of trading for wealth, trading to build your empire, conquering and piracy, or a combination. This has a lot of replay value and can appeal to different players. The main weakness is the mad rush of combat in the final turn (fix with house rules).
The opening positions are not balanced and this bugs the hell out of some players.

item.name: Memoir '44
item.comment: I'm not a wargamer. This has just the right blend of strategy, simulation, and quick play to make me want to play it over and over.

item.name: Merchant of Venus
item.comment: This game has aged well. Discovering new races, racing through trade routes, adjusting when your opponent picks up the cargo first... it's all good. We play to $2000, which includes space stations and factories but doesn't drag out the game.

item.name: Merchants of Amsterdam
item.comment: I love how quickly this game plays. There are many decisions and one choice will help you just a little more than the other, but it never seems to bog down with any analysis paralysis.

item.name: Mice and Mystics
item.comment: This doesn't quite satisfy my RPG itch, but it comes close. It's a simple game with adventure and character advancement that doesn't fall into the trap of being just a random hack & slash where your choices don't matter. Each session is very enjoyable.

item.name: Once Upon a Time: The Storytelling Card Game
Pandemic
item.comment: A great game if you have a group that wants to work together to solve a puzzle. Not so good if someone in your group is dominant or someone is particularly passive. It plays fast, too.

item.name: Pirate Dice: Voyage on the Rolling Seas
Ransom
item.comment:
This is a hidden, under-rated, gem of a game. Will your opponents will squeeze every last dollar of profit out of you for their help? Or will you get your building up first and block them, leaving them with entirely worthless labor and materials?
This game is all about timing and the art of the deal.
This and Citadels are two games that are great to travel with. They're in tiny boxes, the rules are easy, and the possibilities are huge.

item.name: The Resistance: Avalon
item.comment:
I've finally realized that I dislike this genre of game. Werewolf, Avalon, The Resistance, Secret Hitler... I come to hate them. First, someone will argue that you didn't play by working the odds. Second, someone will nuke you because you're perceived as too likely to win. It feels like an argument clinic on cards.
If you like this genre, I think Avalon is my favorite, though Werewolf is fun for a non-gamer campfire game.

item.name: RoboRally
item.comment: This is fun except that (in our play group) very quickly one robot breaks away from the pack and never looks back. It's somewhat more fun if you have an "over and back" race, giving the bots in the back another crack at shooting the leader, but still after a while we felt like the randomness (or player failures) was too much.

item.name: Roll for the Galaxy
item.comment: I usually prefer games with some player-to-player interaction. This has almost none. But with some groups, no spite is really a plus and this is terrific to play with them.

item.name: The Settlers of Catan: 5-6 Player Expansion
item.comment: Imagine: More players, less waiting, no additional complexity. This is a must-have extension. Yes, they're milking us by selling it separately, but there's no doubt about the entertainment value here.

item.name: Silent Death
item.comment: The way the dice are used in combat is *very* unique and interesting.

item.name: Small World
item.comment:
This game is all the fun of Risk only it plays *fast* and the combat options (races and powers) are always fresh.
It's basically a war game with zero tedium. I don't always want to play it (I prefer some negotiation and resource management, maybe alliances, and some luck), but a friend wants a fight, this is it.

item.name: Space Alert
item.comment: This avoids the "decide by committee" aspect of co-operative games like Pandemic by putting everyone into a time-based pressure cooker. There's an interesting balance between delegation and cooperation.

item.name: Space Cadets
item.comment:
The game is just cardboard but the materials are of noticeably worse quality than other games like Space Alert.
The player mats are paper, not cardboard, and on mine the corners were starting to peel. The packing in the box was loose, so when I opened my set things had shaken around so much I thought it was a used set.
Even if the game were simple, it's 6 or more minigames, so it takes quite a while to teach a table of new players. And even on our 3rd play we were still consulting the rules a lot. This slows down the game and the interrupts the feeling of the theme. Maybe more info should be printed on the player mats instead of in the rulebook.
We love this game, but it feels like it needs polish.

item.name: Star Fluxx
item.comment: Fun, silly, a good filler.

item.name: Starfarers of Catan
item.comment:
I like this better than Settlers except that it takes longer to play and I really like games to finish in about two hours.
The exploration is fun, the bonuses from trading with aliens are well balanced, and the additional randomness of the encounter cards is manageable. I find this to be a richer experience with more options.

item.name: Starfarers of Catan: 5-6 Player Expansion
item.comment:
Imagine: More players, less waiting, no additional complexity. This is a must-have extension. Yes, they're milking us by selling it separately, but there's no doubt about the entertainment value here.
The additional map add-ons are high quality and the new race, the Travelers, add to the game. It's easy to see why they're revered by the galaxy. :)
However, more players means a longer game. Be sure not to overlook the expansion rule that doubles the supply cards from Earth, or to use a variant rule to speed things up.

item.name: Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization
Thunderstone
item.comment:
This feels like playing solitaire (with a great theme, cool artwork, and good mechanics) and then comparing your score to the other players at the end.
If you like Dominion or other deck builders, this could be the game for you. I like more player-to-player interaction and this game just isn't that.
I do love how quickly each turn plays.

item.name: Timeline: Inventions
item.comment: This is quick, easy, fun and a nice filler that is less silly than Fluxx and the like. Surprisingly, it's a big hit with my 7th and 9th grade children.

item.name: Warhammer Quest: The Adventure Card Game
The Werewolves of Miller's Hollow
item.comment: My low rating is because I dislike this genre of game. But if you have 8+ players and you're around a campfire, this is a blast. If you play more than three times, it's an argument clinic on cards.

item.name: Xia: Legends of a Drift System
